title: Namibia governor to step down one year ahead of schedule
description:
Johannes !Gawaxab, governor of Namibia’s central bank, will leave his position at the end of 2025, one year before his term is due to expire.

The Bank of Namibia announced today (November 19) that !Gawaxab would leave on December 31, without giving specific reasons. The bank has not named a success...

title: Green Hydrogen Village: Namibia’s Game-Changer in Renewable Energy
description: From the red dunes of Namibia’s Erongo to the buzzing halls of European climate policy, the Daures Green Hydrogen Village is bridging continents and dreams. It’s Africa’s first integrated net-zero community pilot sprawling over 300 hectares, and by mid-2025 it’s set to flood local markets with carbo...

title: Namibia’s Solar Strategy: Balancing Investment and Empowerment in Mining
description: Namibia stands at the precipice of a major energy shift, leveraging its world-leading solar irradiation and expansive, unpopulated territory to fuel a transformation critical to its economy. This transition is particularly vital for the mining sector, where secure, cost-effective energy is paramount...

title: Namibia: It's Time to Transform Namibia's Economy
description:
Namibia's young population, rich resources and strategic location offers us the chance to reshape our economic future but only if we work smart, act fast and innovate boldly.

In a rapidly changing world, simply waiting for growth is not an option. We must create it.

Inspired by historical examples...

title: FNB Namibia Holds Growth Forecast at 3% Despite Q2 Slowdown, Cites Tourism and Farm Rebound
description:
FNB Namibia is maintaining its 3% GDP growth forecast for 2025, betting on a cyclical rebound in agriculture and a strong recovery in the tourism sector, even after the economy slowed more than expected in the second quarter.

Namibia’s real GDP growth decelerated to 1.6% year-on-year in the second ...

title: Namibia: SA Inflation Target Benefits Namibia's Price Stability - Bon
description: An analysis conducted by the Bank of Namibia shows that a lower inflation target of 3% in South Africa will lead to low and stable long-term inflation in Namibia, which is beneficial for price stability. The Bank of Namibia states that the eventual decline in inflation is expected to cause a reducti...
